Ed Malloy. Who was he? Then, it occurred to me: Ed Malloy was my daddy, back when I was Travis.

I went back upstairs and to bed. As I got back under the sheet, I remembered my bedwetting problem, and hoped I wouldn't wake up to dirty sheets in the morning.
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: During the Night

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Any hope I had of not wetting the bed was gone the moment I woke up the next morning. Sitting up in bed, I noticed a large wet spot on my blanket. Uh-oh. Pulling the blanket off, I saw that the sheets and my nightie were soaked with pee.

Jumping out of bed, I tried to think of something to do before anyone found out. “Shame on you, Elizabeth Ann Richardson!”

Too late. Mommy had seen.

Walking over to my bed, pointing at the sheets, she said, “This is why we don’t let you drink anything before bed.” Grabbing the empty juice box from my nightstand, she said, “I hope it was worth sneaking into the kitchen for a drink.”

I hadn’t felt this frightened by Mommy’s yelling since Aaron and Travis had thrown the football inside the apartment. Looking at her, beginning to cry, I said, “I’m sorry Mommy, please don’t be mad at me.”

Seeing me crying must’ve been too much for Mommy; because she also started crying. Kneeling down, she pulled me into a hug. “I’m not mad, sweetie; but you have to listen to Mommy and Daddy if we telling you can’t do something.”

Surprised by Mommy’s crying, I said, “Please don’t cry, Mommy.”

“I’m sorry sweetie; it’s just something with the baby.” Wiping her eyes, she said, “Let me get these sheets in the wash; then I guess we’ll have to give you a bath. You wouldn't want to meet all those other boys and girls smelling like you do now, would you?"
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: The Next Morning

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
After getting me washed up, Mommy got me dressed in a dress with some flowers on it. By that point Daddy had gotten home, having apparently gone to get some coffee and donuts. I was walking down the stairs as he walked into the house.

“I wish time would slow down.” Looking at me, he said, “I can’t believe my little girl is about to start Kindergarten.”

Walking over, Mommy gave Daddy a kiss. “Just think – it wasn’t that long ago she was in diapers.”

The three of us got into the car and drove to the school. I briefly wondered why Daddy was coming; until I remembered he was one of the Kindergarten teachers. Looking at him, I said, “Daddy, will you be my teacher this year?”

“No, kiddo, I won’t; because you’re my daughter, I can’t teach you.” Looking back at me, he said, “But Ms. Eliza is a wonderful teacher, you’ll like her.”

****************************


It was only once we reached the school that I really realized what was going on. Instead of starting 10th Grade with Aaron, I was about to repeat Kindergarten – this time as a little girl. Daddy went ahead to make sure his classroom was ready, leaving Mommy and me to walk into the cafeteria.

It had been almost 5 years since I’d been in the building; it didn’t look that much different since the last time I was here. The lunchroom had the same tables; the only difference I saw was the carpet had been replaced. The only new addition I saw was a small stage in the corner.

After signing us in, Mommy and I walked through the crowd. As we did so, I started to feel a little apprehensive. There were about two dozen kids running around the room – which made me realize something. Until now my only contact with a 5-year-old was with Madison; now I found myself in a situation where I’d be spending five hours a day, five days a week with other 5-year-olds. Would I be able to keep myself from falling too far into Lizzie or would I lose Travis forever?

I was pulled back to reality when I heard Mommy say. “Look, sweetie, there’s Madison and Aaron.”

Looking to where Mommy was pointing, I saw them standing over by the snack table. Running over to them, I immediately hugged Madison. After saying hello to Aaron, as I helped myself to a juice box, Madison said, “How are you doing?”

“I’m doing good.” Sipping my juice box, I looked at Aaron and said, “Do you remember Mrs. Wilcox from Child Services?”

“I remember her trying to take you away from your mom a few times.” Confused, Aaron said, “Why?”

“It turns out she’s my daddy’s sister.” Pausing, I said, “She’s having a baby and she's Lebanese.”

A confused look on his face, Aaron looked at me and said, “She’s Lebanese?”

For the second time in two days, I found myself struggling to find a word that I know I remembered. Looking at Aaron, I said, "What's that thing where girls like girls?"

"Oh, you mean she’s a lesbian.”

Lesbian! That’s the word! “Thank you, I couldn’t remember the word.” Throwing out the empty juice box, I turned to Aaron and said, “Could you do me a favor and look up Ed Malloy for me?”

“I suppose I could do that.” Looking at me, Aaron said, “But why? Who’s he supposed to be?”

“I think he’s Travis’ daddy.”

Before we could talk further, I heard a woman’s voice say, “We’re about to start; if the children could have a seat in front of the stage.”
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Meet & Greet, Pt 1

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
After all the kids were seated in front of the stage, an older woman walked up to the microphone. “Hello children; my name is Mrs. Collins, I’m the school principal here at Beaumont Elementary.” Looking around the room, she said, “I’m sure most of you are nervous about starting Kindergarten, and that’s alright. Over the next year, you’ll learn many new things and make new friends.”

I found myself looking around at all the other kids; finding it amusing that before last week, I probably never would have met any of them. Now, due to a mysterious stone, I was likely going to be with them through High School. Madison must’ve noticed me looking around. Turning to me, she said, “Are you okay, Lizzie?”

“Uh-huh.” Looking at her, I said, “I’m just thinking about how I’m starting school all over again.”

Reaching her hand towards me, she said, “At least we’ll have each other, right?”

As I took Madison’s hand, I came to another realization. Thanks to her wish; as far as everyone knew, the two of us were best friends. We’d be spending a lot of our time together over the next year. Looking at her, I said, “Of course, we’ll have each other.”

We both turned our attention back to the principal, who’d just finished talking about some of what we’d be learning this year. I watched as Daddy and a woman walked onto the stage and stand behind Principal Collins. “Now before I hand you off to your teachers, I want to wish all of you luck.”

**************************


It took about 10 minutes for all the kids to be matched up with their teachers. Although I remembered Daddy saying something a few days ago, I was relieved that Madison and I were in the same class. The two of us were standing towards the center of the group when the woman, who looked to be about Mommy and Daddy’s age, turned to face us.

Pushing her glasses up onto her nose, she said, “Hello boys and girls; I’m Ms. Eliza and I’ll be your teacher.” Looking at us, she said, “I’m sure we’re all going to have a good time together, won’t we?”

All 15 of us, in unison, said, “Yes, Ms. Eliza!”

With that, Ms. Eliza got all of us into a single file line and led us out of the cafeteria. It was a short walk down the hall to the kindergarten wing. Opening a door, she gestured for all of us to go inside. As we walked into the room, both Madison and I looked around with awestruck expressions on our faces. The room was huge, at least from my perspective; with 3 tables situated in the center, each with 5 chairs around them. I also saw a play corner with lots of toys and a fairly extensive library of children’s books. Looking at me, Madison said, “This is so cool!”

“It’s way better than the last time I was in Kindergarten.”

It was clear from the chorus of ‘wow’ and ‘cool’ that our classmates shared our enthusiasm. Making her way through the jumble of kids, Ms. Eliza stopped in front of the chalkboard. “Welcome to your classroom, boys and girls. As you can see, there are many things we’ll be covering this year.” Smiling, she said, “Now why don’t we all take a seat; then we’ll go around the room and introduce ourselves.”

Wanting to stick together, Madison and I quickly grabbed two seats at the nearest table. We were soon joined by two boys and another girl. The girl, for some reason, stuck out to me. She wore glasses like Ms. Eliza and it was clear she wasn't quite used to them. “Hi.” Offering my hand, I said, “I’m Lizzie, and this is Madison.”

“It’s nice to meet you, I’m Rachel.” Shaking my hand, she said, “I really like your dress.”

After that, we listened as everyone else introduced themselves. As I sat at the table, looking around the room, I found myself thinking - Maybe being in kindergarten again won’t be as bad as I thought.
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Meet & Greet, Pt 2

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
We stayed in the classroom for around an hour before Ms. Eliza brought us back to the cafeteria. As we walked into the room, Madison and I said goodbye to Rachel. I watched as she ran to a nearby table and hugged two men. I wonder if they’re lesbians like Auntie Megan.

Turning my attention away from Rachel, I followed Madison as we made our way through the crowd. It didn’t take long for us to find Mommy talking Aaron and Madison’s Mom. The two of us ran up to the group, big smiles on our faces. Turning to us,
Mommy said, “Hello girls, how was it with Ms. Eliza?”

In unison, we said, “Great!”

“Did you make any new friends?”

“Uh-huh; her name’s Rachel and she gots glasses like Ms. Eliza.”

The two of us answered some more questions about what happened; some of whom came from Aaron. I figured he was trying to see if I’d regressed more than I already have. I had a little, but I didn’t really care. Suddenly we heard someone behind us clear their throat. We all turned around to find Rachel standing there with the two men I’d seen her hug moments earlier.

Reaching out his hand, one of them said, “My name is Thomas Anderson, and this is my husband Anthony; we’re Rachel’s parents.”

“It’s nice to meet you both.” Shaking their hands, Mommy said, “I’m Melanie and this is Grace and Aaron.”

After introductions had been made, Anthony said, “It’s nice to see another same-sex couple here; Thomas and I were wondering if we would.”

“Oh sorry, we’re not a couple.” Blushing, Mommy said, “My husband is the other Kindergarten teacher.”

“Oh my, I’m so sorry.” Wincing, Anthony said, “I saw the two of you talking, and I just assumed you were a couple.”

“Nope, we’re not.” Smiling, Mrs. Sullivan said, “We’re just close friends; Lizzie and Madison have been friends practically since they were born.”

“Rachel couldn’t stop talking about them; we’re new to the area and she was afraid she wouldn’t make any friends.” Looking at Madison and me, Thomas said, “Thanks, girls, for making our daughter feel welcome.”

“You can never have enough friends.”

After that, the adults went back to talking with each other while Aaron kept an eye on us kids. A few minutes went by before we all realized we had to use the bathroom. Aaron escorted us to the bathroom and offered to wait outside. Before I could go in, he stopped me and pulled me aside. Looking at me, he said, “So, how was it?”

“How was what?”

“Don’t play stupid with me, Travis.” Sighing, Aaron said, “What was it like being around all those kids?”

“First off, my name’s Lizzie.” Pausing, I said, “Second, it wasn’t that bad. I actually think I’m going to enjoy kindergarten.”

“You’re joking, right?” With an incredulous look, Aaron said, “We were both supposed to be starting the 10th grade; now you’re back in Kindergarten.”

“I’m not joking, Aaron.” Sighing, I said, “Like it or not, I have the emotional maturity of a 5-year-old; Kindergarten is the best thing for me right now.”

“If you say so.” Sighing, Aaron said, “I just hope you’ll be your old self again once we undo the wish.”

I didn’t want Aaron to know that I was beginning to have serious doubts about undoing the wish. “One can only hope, right.” Looking at him, I said, “Now if you don’t mind, I really have to go potty.”

*********************


We stayed at the school for another twenty minutes or so; not before Mommy and Mrs. Sullivan made plans for Madison and me to have a play date with Rachel this weekend. After saying goodbye to Aaron and Madison, Mommy put me in the booster seat. As Mommy got in the car, I realized Daddy wasn’t there. “Where’s Daddy?”

“He has to stay for a little while.” Looking at me, Mommy said, “But don’t worry sweetie, we’ll pick him up after we go to the doctor’s office.”

I don’t know why, but hearing the term doctor’s office sent chills down my spine. Looking at Mommy, I said, “Why are we going to the doctor?”

“The school requires us to make sure you’re properly vaccinated, sweetie.” Pausing, Mommy said, “I know you don’t like shots; but if you’re brave, we’ll get some ice cream afterward.”

I tried my best to hide my anxiety – Travis never liked shots and it was clear that Lizzie didn’t like them either. Looking at Mommy, I said, “O-Okay mommy.”
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Meet & Greet, Pt 3

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
"Well, good afternoon!" said the doctor, an older lady with big glasses. "You must be Lizzie!" Turning to Mommy, she asked, "And what brings Lizzie in this afternoon?"

"Making sure her vaccinations are up to date," Mommy answered. "I should warn you, she's not a big fan of needles."

"Not to worry, I've dealt with many children who didn't like needles. Step one." She pulled out a tin that was full of suckers. "See them all? And so many flavors, too! Why, I'll bet that you could find your favorite in here, no trouble at all, right?"

I nodded. I could already see my favorite.

"Well, I'll tell you what let's do: if you can be a brave little girl while we give you your shots, then you can reach in and take any sucker you want. Agreed?"

I had to agree. I wanted that sucker, even more than I was scared of needles.

"Alright. Now, we go on to step two." A nurse sat down in front of me. "The nurse is going to read a short story, Lizzie, and I would like for you to pay close attention as she reads. Can you do that, Lizzie?"

Could I ever! I sat and listened as she read her story.

When she closed her book, I said, "Okay, I'm ready for my shots now."

"Are you? Well, that's too bad, because I already gave you your shots."

My eyes widened.

"It's true. I gave you your shots while you were listening to the story." She brought back the tin of suckers. "Here. I'm a woman of my word. You can take two."

As soon as I had two cherry suckers, Mom took me out of the doctor's office, and to the ice cream shop, where I got a big hot fudge sundae. Beat that, Aaron.
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: At the Doctor

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
I had to use the bathroom after having my sundae, so Mommy waited for me outside while I went. After a few minutes went by, I walked outside just as she got off the phone. Looking at me, she said, “Sweetie, how would you feel if we stopped by the Ballet School on our way to pick up daddy?”

Maybe it was the sugar, or maybe it was the adrenaline from the doctor’s office – but I started jumping up and down. “Yes!!”

It was only about a 5-minute drive to Ms. Benson’s Dance Academy. As we walked inside the building, I caught a glimpse of a few girls having a lesson in a nearby room. From what I could tell, they looked to be close to Travis’ age. Maybe this won’t be so bad; I get to be around pretty girls.

I held Mommy’s hand as she walked up to a nearby counter. After a moment, an older woman came out of a nearby doorway. “Hello, what can I do for you today?”

“I was wondering if you had any available spots in your beginner’s ballet class?” gesturing to me, Mommy said, “My daughter wants to learn ballet.”

“It just so happens that we have one more spot available.” Turning to me, she said, “What might your name be, little one?”

I was suddenly overcome with shyness. After a moment, I said, “Lizzie.”

“It’s nice to meet you, Lizzie.” Smiling, she said, “I’m Gloria, and this is my dance academy.”

************************


I was sitting in the waiting area with Mommy, reading a children’s book while she filled out the paperwork. At least I was attempting to read it – I suddenly found myself having trouble with some of the bigger words.

I was just about to give up in frustration when I heard someone call my name. “Lizzie!”

Looking up from the book, I watched as Rachel walked out of a nearby room with one of her daddy’s. Putting the book down, I ran over and hugged her, “Hi Rachel!”

It took me a moment to realize the man with her was her father Thomas. Looking at me, he said, “Hello Lizzie, it’s nice to see you again.”

I was suddenly overcome with shyness again. I was saved from having to say anything when Mommy walked over. “Hello
Rachel, Hello Thomas.”

“Hello again, Melanie.” Looking at Mommy, Thomas said, “What brings you two here?”

“I’m just signing Lizzie up for the beginner’s ballet class.” Pausing, Mommy said, “What about you two?”

“I was just signing Rachel up as well; I guess our girls took the last two spots.”

“I guess so.” Looking around, Mommy said, “Where’s Anthony?”

“He got called into work; there was a car crash on the highway.”

“I just realized I never asked what you both did for a living.”

“Well I’m an interior decorator; I just started as the manager of Brightburn Interiors. My better half works as an EMT.” Smiling, Thomas said, “How about you? What do you do?”

“Well, as I said at the Meet & Greet, my husband Peter is one of the Kindergarten teachers.” Smiling, Mommy said, “Myself, I’m a reporter for the Channel 7 News.”

“Now that you mention it, I remember watching your pregnancy announcement,” turning to me, Thomas said, “Are you excited to be a big sister, Lizzie?”

When I didn’t respond again, Mommy said, “I think she’s a little overwhelmed with all the new people she’s met today.” Pausing, she said, “She didn’t take the news well at first, but I think she’s coming around.

After talking for a few minutes, Thomas said, “We should probably get going; Rachel is very excited to try on her ballet outfit when we get home.”

It was then that I realized he was carrying a wrapped up ballet outfit. Turning to Mommy, I said, “Mommy, can I wear mine when we get home?”

“Of course sweetie.” Turning to Thomas, Mommy said, “It was nice seeing you both again.”

“It was nice to see you again too, Melanie.”
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Signing up for Ballet

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
It had been almost 2 hours since we all got home. Almost immediately I ran upstairs to change into my new ballet outfit. A small part of me was a little disturbed by how excited I was – but a growing part of me didn’t care. As I put the package on my bed, I looked at what it contained; a pair of ballet slippers and a pink leotard with a little skirt around the bottom.

I spent the next few hours running around the house; doing my best attempts at some ballet moves. There were several times where I slipped but I quickly got back up. I was up in my room, having a tea party when I heard the doorbell ring.

Walking out of my room, I went to see who was at the door. I stopped around the corner when I heard Mommy said, “Hello Aaron, what can I do for you?”

“Hi, Mrs. Richardson.” Pausing, Aaron said, “I was coming back from practice, and thought I’d come to see how Lizzie was doing. I know she doesn’t particularly care for the doctor’s office.”

Peaking around the corner, I was surprised to see Aaron wearing what looked to be a football uniform. What’s going on, Aaron doesn’t play football.

“Well aren’t you sweet; she actually did very well.” Pausing, Mommy said, “She’s upstairs in her room.”

Uh-oh. Quickly running back to my room, I debated whether or not to change out of my ballet outfit. I could hear footsteps coming up the stairs; but before I could make a decision, I saw Aaron walk into my room. He stopped in his tracks when he saw me in the ballet outfit.

Looking at Aaron, feeling a little embarrassed, I said, “How do you like my outfit?”
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Back Home

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Aaron was clearly taken aback by my outfit; I could tell from the shocked look on his face. I was starting to feel a little insecure – worried that I didn’t look as pretty as I thought I did. When Aaron hadn’t responded for a few moments, I said, “Don’t I look pretty?”

“Yes.” Looking at me, Aaron said, “You look v-very pretty, Lizzie.”

“Thanks!” giggling, I grabbed his hand and pulled him into my room. “So what’s with all that stuff?”

“Oh this?” gesturing to his football gear, Aaron said, “It turns out that I’m on the football team now.”

“Really?” looking at him, I said, “You suck at football, why would they let you on the team?”

“I guess I’m good at it in this reality.” Shrugging, Aaron said, “I saw some photos at the house; apparently I’ve been playing youth football since I was 7 years old.”

“So I’m born a girl instead of a boy; suddenly you’re playing football?”

“That’s not all.” Looking at me, Aaron said, “With Travis...out of the picture, it seems my best friend is Colin Sheppard; who’s the Quarterback.”

Colin Sheppard, at least prior to the wish, had been kind of a geek. It was strange to think that my being a girl now had affected so many people’s lives. Walking over to my tea set, I said, “Do you have time for a tea party?”

“As fun as that sounds, I don’t have the time.” Looking at me, Aaron said, “I just stopped by to see how you were doing; I know you used to hate shots and figured it was the case now.”

“Actually the doctor did a good job distracting me; a nurse read me a story and before I knew it, I’d gotten all my shots.” Rubbing my arm, I said, “I am feeling a little sore though.”

“I’m glad to hear the shots didn’t bother you, but that’s not what I meant.” Looking at me, Aaron said, “I was surprised to see you so excited to wear that outfit.”

“Is it a crime that I want to try it out before ballet?”

“No, I...it’s just the Travis I knew would never be caught dead wearing something like that.”

“This would never fit Travis; it’s too small for him, silly.”

Kneeling down to my level, Aaron looked at me and said, “Answer this question for me; do you actually like the outfit, or are you just doing this because you’re a little girl?”

“Does it really matter?” taking a breath, I said, “I like this outfit because it makes me feel like a princess.”

“Can you stop talking like that!” getting agitated, Aaron said, “You may look like a 5-year-old girl, but that doesn’t mean you have to act like one. You’re a teenage boy for god’s sake.”

“I’m not an icky, booger-faced boy!” starting to get upset, I said, “I’m a pretty little girl!”

“Dammit Travis; you’re not supposed to be a little girl!”

“You said a bad word!” making my way towards the door, I said, “I’m going to tell my mommy!”

Before I could make it to the door, Aaron stood in my way. “Are you seriously telling me dammit is a bad word?” looking at me, he said, “Come on Travis, your favorite word has an M and an F in it!”

“My name’s not Travis!” trying to get past Aaron, I said, “Stop calling me Travis!”

“That’s it, I’ve got to put a stop to this before you completely become a girl.” Going to open the door, Aaron said, “I’ve got to find another stone so I can put things back the way they were.”

I don’t know whether it was out of fear or just exhaustion; frankly, it could have been both. Before Aaron could even start to turn the doorknob, I fell to the floor and started crying. It didn’t take long for Mommy to come running into the room. Seeing me in tears on the floor, she turned to Aaron and said, “What happened?”

“I don’t know, we were just talking.” Pausing, Aaron said, “I must’ve said something wrong because suddenly she started crying.”
“I’m sure it wasn’t anything you did, Aaron.” Picking me up off the floor, Mommy said, “It’s been a pretty eventful day, I think she’s just tired.”

I didn’t know what it would accomplish, but part of me wanted to get Aaron in trouble. Turning from him to mommy, I said, “Mommy, Aaron said a bad word!”

Mommy turned to Aaron with a shocked look on her face. “What did you say, Aaron?”

“I may have accidentally said the word dammit.” Pausing, he said, “I’m sorry, it just slipped out.”

“You should be more careful Aaron; Lizzie’s at an impressionable age." heading towards my bed, Mommy said, "Her father and I don’t want her to repeat that kind of language.”

As Mommy turned to carry me over to the bed, Aaron glared at me. Walking up behind her, Aaron said, “I’m sorry, Mrs. Richardson, it won’t happen again.”

************************


Although Aaron left a few minutes later, I was still worried about his wanting to use the stone. I didn’t want to lose this life; even if it meant being a girl. After getting me out of the ballet outfit and into some pajamas, Mommy put me down for a nap.
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: A Confrontation

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
After my nap, I had a bunch of things going through my head. Luckily, I had just the way to work things out: a tea party.

"I have some news to share," I said. "I'm taking ballet lessons." I showed them what I'd learned.

"Brava!" said Mrs. Honeysnout. "I predict a command performance before the crowned heads of Europe!"

"Your life is simply amazing," said Mrs. Whiskertail.

"So many things are different now," I said. "For some reason, me not being Travis means Aaron and Colin are football players. Can you explain it?"

"And he wants to throw that away?" asked Mrs. Snifflepuss.

"He doesn't like me being a little girl."

"And he intends to change that as soon as he can," said Mrs. Whiskertail, "doesn't he?"

"As soon as he finds another wishing stone. How can I stop him?"

"There's only one way," Mrs. Whiskertail said. "When he finds a stone, you have to get it before he can use it."

"And then?"

"You have to make a wish of your own. One that will keep him from trying to wish you into a boy."

"I don't want to hurt him, Mrs. Whiskertail."

"You're not going to wish to hurt him. Just make a wish that will make sure that, when he can make that wish, he won't want to anymore."
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Later On

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
A few days had passed since my argument with Aaron; it was now Saturday. Almost everyone was in the backyard for the end of the summer BBQ that Mommy and Daddy were throwing. I spent most of the first 30 minutes or so hanging around my grandparents.

It was strange being around Mommy’s parents; I’d only ever heard nasty things about how they disowned Mommy after she’d gotten pregnant with Travis. Instead of wanting nothing to do with mommy and me; now they were spoiling me. I guess it helped that, at least for now, I was their only grandchild.

I spent some more time with Daddy’s parents too; since I hadn’t had the opportunity to see them much earlier in the week. Poppa, as he liked to be called, was showing me some magic tricks when we heard the gate open behind me. Turning around, I saw Auntie Megan walking over with another woman following behind her. It didn’t take a genius to realize that the other woman was Auntie Amber.

Jumping off of Poppa’s lap, I ran over to them; barging into Auntie Megan harder than I’d meant to. “Oof.” Kneeling down, Auntie Megan said, “Before careful sweetie, you don’t want to hurt the baby.”

“Sorry, Auntie Megan.”

After giving me a kiss, Megan got up and walked over to the adults; leaving me alone with Auntie Amber. I was a little awkward around her; knowing next to nothing about her except that she was Auntie Megan’s wife. She was very pretty; tall with brown hair.
“Hi kiddo, are you excited for your first day of school on Monday?”

“Uh-huh.” Looking at her, I said, “I’m also ‘cited about ballet.”

“Your mommy told me you were doing that.” Smiling, Amber said, “I’m sure you’re going to do great.”

*********************


Aaron and Madison arrived with their parents a short time later. Once everyone was settled, Daddy stepped in front of everyone. “Melanie and I want to thank you all for coming.” Gesturing to Madison and me, he said, “It seems like only yesterday that these adorable girls were in diapers, but come Monday they’re going to be starting Kindergarten.”

Madison and I stood there, feeling a little embarrassed, as everyone stared at us. Turning his attention to the Sullivan’s, daddy said, “Kevin, Diane; who would’ve thought, 7 years ago, when I was assigned Aaron’s 2nd-grade class as a student teacher, that we’d become such good friends.” Smiling, Daddy said, “I love Aaron and Madison like they’re my own kids; just as you love Lizzie.”

Daddy wrapped up his little speech a moment later; as everyone gave a toast. Once that was finished, Madison and I ran over to the little playhouse. I was about to go inside when Aaron walked over and said, “Lizzie, can I come in?”

“Uh-Uh.” Trying my best to look angry, I said, “There are no icky boys allowed in my playhouse.”

“Lizzie, please...”

“No boys!”

After Aaron walked off, defeated, I went inside and closed the door. Looking at me, Madison said, “So, uh, what’s going on between Aaron and you?”

I proceeded to explain what happened a few days prior. When I was finished, I said, “I don’t want Aaron to undo the wish.” Pausing, I said, “I like being a girl.”

“You do?”

“Yeah.” Pausing, I said, “Sometimes my boy mind sneaks through, but most of the time I’m thinking and acting like a little girl.”

“What if Aaron finds a stone and undoes the wish anyway?”

“Mrs. Whiskertail suggested that I make my own wish.”

“Who’s Mrs. Whiskertail?”

“She’s my stuffed animal rabbit.” Looking at Madison, I said, “I, uh, talk to her and the other stuffed animals.”

I was worried Madison would think I was crazy. Instead, she looked at me and said, “Can I talk to them too?”

“Sure!” grabbing Madison’s hand, I said, “Let’s go up to my room.”

Madison and I ran out of the playhouse; making our way towards the kitchen door. On our way, I saw that Becky had shown up; she was currently in a passionate kiss with Aaron. As I ran past them, I could hear Mommy said, “Aaron, Becky, could you both tone it down a little around the kids?”

Running upstairs, Madison and I ran into my room only to stop in our tracks when we saw the psychic lady standing by my bed.
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: The Barbeque

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
"Oh, there you are, Lizzie," Madame Burke said, as if her being in my bedroom was the most natural thing in the world.

"What are you doing in my room?" I demanded.

"You have a great destiny before you, Elizabeth Richardson," she replied. "Come with me, and I shall prepare you."

"I've already got a density!" I shot back, not caring that I messed up the word. "I'm gonna be a ballerina!"

"You are to bring forth the Messiah!"

"I don't wanna bring anybody, forth or fifth or anything!"

"Is that a fact?" she asked, digging through her robes. "Fortunately, I have a way to... persuade you."

She pulled out her hand, which was holding...

"A wishing stone!"

The old woman raised the stone to her lips, and I was scared of what she might wish...

... Until she screamed in agony, as Madison sank her teeth into Madame Burke's leg. Even better, the bite made her drop the wishing stone, which I kicked away.

By this time, somebody must have heard something, because Mommy came into my room, followed by Aaron. "Lizzie! Lizzie, are you okay?" she asked, giving me the hug of my life.

"What happened, Aunt Mel?" Aaron asked.

"That - " She looked around the room. We all did. "I thought I saw an old woman in here."

Madame Burke was gone.
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Continue

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
A few minutes passed before everyone else came running upstairs; before too long there were over a dozen people in crammed into my tiny bedroom. Madison and I clung to both our mommy’s; as the two of us were rather shaken up by what just transpired.
Walking into the room, the phone in hand, Daddy said, “I’m on the phone with the Police; they want to know if you have a description of the woman.”

Mommy proceeded to describe Madame Burke to Daddy. Once she finished, Mommy said, “How could she sneak in here without any of us knowing?”

She has a magic stone; I’m thinking she can do anything. Looking at Mommy, I said, “Is the scary lady going to come back?”

“Of course not, sweetie.” Giving me a kiss on the forehead, she said, “We’ll make sure she never comes back to harm you.”

After getting off the phone, Daddy said, “The cops will be here in a few minutes.” Kneeling down, he looked at Madison and me.

“Girls, did she say anything before the screaming started?”

Madison was still too shaken up to answer, but I managed to calm myself. Looking at Daddy, I said, “She said I had a great density; that I was going to bring forth the messy.”

Daddy and Mommy shared quizzical looks with each other; clearly Daddy wasn’t satisfied with my answer. Looking at him, Mommy said, “A strange woman was just in her room, Peter; I don’t think that interrogating our daughter is the best thing right now.”

“I’m not interrogating her, Melanie.” Sighing, Daddy said, “I just want to know everything I can.”

While the other adults were talking, Aaron stepped forward and said, “Mr. Richardson, perhaps I can try talking to them?”

“Well, it’s worth a shot.” Getting up, Daddy said, “Aaron, we’ll be downstairs waiting for the cops.”

After everyone left the room, Aaron closed the door. Turning his attention back to us, he said, “Would you two like to tell me what’s going on here?”

I didn’t want Aaron knowing I talked with my stuffed animals, so I had to fib a little. “Madison and I were coming up here to...to play with my stuffed animals.” Pausing, I said, “We got up here and found Madame Burke waiting by my bed.”

“She said Lizzie had some destiny or something; that she was going to bring forth the Messiah.” Looking at Aaron, Madison said,
“Lizzie refused and then she took out a stone; saying she had a way to persuade her.”

“Wait, she had a stone?”

“Uh-huh.” Gesturing to my bed, I said, “After Madison bit her, she dropped it and I kicked it under my bed.”
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: The Aftermath

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
The police finally arrived about 20 minutes after Daddy called them. There were two of them; a young man in his 20s and a middle-aged woman. While the young man was downstairs, the woman came into my room; where I was waiting with Mommy, Aaron and Madison.

Taking one look around the room, the lady turned to everyone and said, “I’d like to speak with the child please; in private.”
Sighing, she said, “The crime scene is well and truly trampled, so please give me the courtesy of allowing us to speak.”

I guess trampling a crime scene was a bad thing, because everyone left my room with their heads down. Once everyone was out of the room, the officer closed the door and came over to me. Kneeling down, she smiled at me and said, “Hello sweetie, my name’s Doris. What’s yours?”

“Elizabeth Ann Richardson.” Smiling, I said, “But everyone calls me Lizzie.”

“It’s nice to meet you, Lizzie.” Pausing, Doris said, “So what do you like to do in your room?”

"I like tea parties." I showed her the table. "Would you like to join me?"

"I'd be delighted."

I rearranged the chairs so Doris had room to kneel. Gesturing to each of the animals, I introduced them. "This is Mrs. Snifflepuss, Mrs. Whiskertail, and Mrs. Honeysnout. Ladies, this is Doris."

I knew Doris probably thought it was childish, but I was happy that she played along. "Delighted to make your acquaintance.”

With Doris at the table, I did notice something funny; I couldn’t hear the ladies talking like I did when I was alone. After a while of us sipping pretend tea, Doris said, “Lizzie, I’d like to ask you about what happened here today; if that’s alright with you.”

“Okay."

"Did you see the lady who got in here?"

"Uh-huh." Pausing, I said, “She was old and scary looking.”

“Did she say anything to you?”

“Uh-huh.” Nodding, I said, “She said it was my density to bring forth the messy."

“I see.” Nodding, Doris said, “What did you say to that?”

“I told her I wanted to be a ballerina.”

After asking a few more questions, and having some more sips of her tea, Doris got up to leave. I followed her down the hall and watched as she went downstairs to speak with Mommy and Daddy. “I'd recommend you get a security system, Mr. Richardson. That might keep this person away next time."
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: The Cops Arrive

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
The party started back up after that cops left; but not to the same extent it had been before Madame Burke. After a while, everyone decided it was time to leave; except for Aaron and Madison.

After his folks left, Aaron came up to my room with Madison following behind him. Once he closed the door, he bent down and retrieved the stone from under my bed. “Great; now that we finally have one of these, we can undo this stupid wish and things can get back to normal.”

I was suddenly reminded of what Mrs. Whiskertail had said; about making sure Aaron didn’t undo the wish. Before Aaron could stop me, I ran up and grabbed the stone out of his hand. “I don’t want to undo the wish!”

“Are you being serious right now, Travis?” scoffing, Aaron looked at me and said, “From the moment this happened, we’ve been searching for a way to undo this; now you’re telling me you don’t want to.”

“That’s right.” Getting nervous, I said, “I-I kind of like being a little girl.”

“What?” looking at me, Aaron said, “Please tell me you’re joking.”

“I’m not joking, Aaron.” Sighing, I said, “Sure; when this happened I wanted to undo it. But now, after living this life for almost a week, I-I don’t want to.”

“What could possibly have changed your mind?”

“Do you really have to ask me that?” looking at him, I said, “Look around; does this look like that crappy apartment I used to live in? Now I’ve got two loving parents instead of a single, overworked druggie for a mom.”

“Those are all good points, but come on; you’re really telling me being a 5-year-old girl is what you want?”

“Yes.” Holding the stone close, I said, “Please don’t ruin this for me.”

After a moment's hesitation, Aaron finally said, “Okay fine, I won’t undo the wish; at least not yet.” Sighing, he said, “Just give me the stone; if this situation has taught us anything, it’s that 5-year-old girls shouldn’t use one of these.”

I reluctantly gave Aaron the stone; hoping I hadn’t made a big mistake. With the stone in hand, Aaron turned to Madison and said, “Come on Maddy, let's go home.”

As she followed Aaron out of the room, Madison said, “I promise I’ll make sure he doesn’t undo the wish.”
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: The Wishing Stone

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
I didn’t sleep very well that night; probably from worrying about Madame Burke or that Aaron would go back on his promise. I hoped that I would be able to convince Aaron not to undo the wish; hopefully, he would realize that I was happy like this.

My worries must’ve shown through; because when I came down for breakfast the next morning, Mommy took one look at me and said, “What’s wrong, sweetie?”

“I scared of the crazy lady.” Looking at Mommy, I said, “She’s not coming back for me, is she?”

“I promise you, sweetie, that she’ll never come near you again.” Kneeling down, Mommy said, “Now why don’t you have some
breakfast; Rachel and Madison will be here in a couple of hours.
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: The Next Day

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Rachel and her daddies were the first to arrive; Rachel was holding one of her dolls while her daddy Thomas was carrying a bottle of some dark liquid. Referencing the bottle, Thomas said, “I was thinking the adults could have some wine while the kids play.”

It wasn’t long before Madison arrived with her folks. When I didn’t see Aaron, I got concerned. Looking at Madison, I said,
“Where’s Aaron?”

“He went to the beach with Becky.” Pausing, Madison said, “Don’t worry; he didn’t bring the stone with him.”

I breathed a sigh of relief upon hearing that; now I didn’t have to worry about that ruining my play date.

*************************


While Rachel, Madison and I spent our time in the play area; the parents were chatting nearby. I wasn’t paying much attention, but I did hear a few pieces of their conversation. “So, you two, how did you end up with Rachel?” pausing, Mommy said, “My sister-in-law and her wife used a sperm donor.”

“Our method wasn’t as conventional as that.” With a glance at Anthony, Thomas said, “You see I was born female; we simply combined one of my eggs with Anthony’s sperm, making us both Rachel’s biological parents.”

“I’ve heard stories about trans men having babies, I just never imagined meeting one.” Looking at Thomas, Mrs. Sullivan said, “If you don’t mind my asking; how did that affect your mental health, identifying as a man but enduring the changes that come with pregnancy.”

“There were some difficult times; especially once my breasts started getting bigger.” Taking Anthony’s hand, Thomas said, “But I have an amazingly supportive husband, and we now have an amazing little girl.”

“Does Rachel have any idea?”

“Not yet; we figured we’d wait until she was older.”

At that point, Mommy turned her attention to the three of us, in the midst of a tea party with our dolls. “It’s amazing, isn’t it?
Madison and Lizzie have been friends since they were babies, and they were so quick to accept Rachel into their little group.”

“Kids are like that; they don’t see race or gender.” Smiling, Anthony said, “Everyone is the same to them.”

“I don’t know about the rest of you, but I can’t believe our little girls are starting kindergarten tomorrow.”

“Time sure flies, doesn’t it?”
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: A Few Hours Later

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
When I woke up the next morning, I quickly remembered what day it was. It was my first day of Kindergarten and, not surprisingly, I was looking forward to it. I don’t really know what caused the change in my attitude; but over the last few days, as today got closer, I got more and more excited about the prospect of going back to Kindergarten. Sure there was a part of me that wished I was still in High School with Aaron, but that part was slowly fading away.

I was sitting up in bed when Mommy and Daddy came into the room; with Daddy holding a video camera. I wondered what they were doing until I realized they were doing what most parents would do; videotaping their child on her first day of school. Mommy was already in tears as she sat next to me. “I promised myself I wouldn’t cry, but I can’t believe my little girl is starting Kindergarten.”

“She’s growing up so fast.” Turning the camera to me, Daddy said, “Lizzie, sweetie, are you excited for your first day?”

“Uh-huh!” giggling, I said, “I very ‘cited, daddy!”

Having composed herself, Mommy said, “Let’s get you ready; the school bus is going to be here soon.”

**************************


It didn’t take long for me to get ready; after taking a quick bath, Mommy got me dressed up in the outfit she’d picked out – a nice floral print dress. I was starting to get excited, so I was squirming around as she tried to put a bow in my hair. Thank god Aaron won’t see this.

After having a bowl of cereal, I grabbed my Frozen backpack and went outside. Holding Mommy’s hand, while Daddy recorded, we walked the half a block to the bus stop. When we got there I saw a few kids from the meet & greet, none of whom were in my class, as well as a few 2nd and 3rd graders. I started to get nervous at this point; it really hit me that I was starting Kindergarten again. I should have been starting 10th grade with Aaron, but now I was back in Kindergarten with kids who hadn’t been born yet when Travis had started Kindergarten.

I kept to myself while I waited for the bus; I didn’t know the other Kindergarteners and the big kids wouldn’t show any interest in a
5-year-old girl. Meanwhile, Mommy and Daddy were talking with the other parents. I found myself wishing that Madison had the same bus stop as me, so at least I’d have a friend to talk to.

It wasn’t long before the school bus arrived; I was the last one to get on. I hesitated briefly, looking back towards Mommy and Daddy, before taking a deep breath and stepping onto the bus. Here goes nothing.
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: First Day of School

1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
When I got off the bus at school, the first thing I did was look for Rachel and Madison. I quickly spotted them standing over by the flagpole. Running up to them, I saw they were wearing similar outfits to mine. “Hey guys!” smiling, I said, “What are we waiting for?”

“Ms. Eliza had to go inside real quick.” Looking at me, Madison said, “She said she was going to bring us all in at once.”

“I don’t know about you guys, but I’m kind of nervous.”

“There’s nothing to be nervous about, Rachel.” Turning to Rachel, I said, “You’ll have Madison and me with you.”

That was enough to put a smile on Rachel’s face as she walked over to a bench to sit down. Once she was out of earshot, Madison looked at me and said, “How are you doing?”

I realized what she was talking about; so I looked at her and said, “I’m kind of nervous; I was supposed to be starting 10th grade today, not going back to Kindergarten.”

“If you’re that nervous, why not just let Aaron change you back?”

“I’m not sure I want him to.” Sighing, I said, “Yes, I’m nervous about starting kindergarten again, but that doesn’t mean I want to give up this life.”

It was at that point Ms. Eliza and Daddy came out of the building to gather their respective classes. I gave an excited wave when I saw Daddy looking at me. Ms. Eliza got all of us into 2 single file lines before leading us into the building.
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Arriving at School

choices: The Second Half of the Day
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
The first half of the day went by without any problems; once everyone was seated, Ms. Eliza started the class by teaching us some letters of the alphabet. Deep down I knew what the letters were but as I sat at the table with Rachel and Madison, I had some difficulty remembering what they were. I guess what Madame Burke had said was coming true; as time went by; I would start losing some of what I’d learned as Travis.

That became readily apparent when it came for us the class to color some drawings of the letters A B and C. I was by no means a skilled artist before all this, but I knew how to stay in the lines. Now, as Lizzie, I was having a really hard time doing it. I was actually starting to get a little frustrated by my inability to do so.

Eventually, I got to the point where I threw the crayon down in frustration. Rachel and Madison looked up at me briefly before returning to their coloring – they had no problem staying in the lines. Ms. Eliza must’ve noticed I was getting frustrated, as she walked over and knelt down next to me. “What’s wrong, Lizzie?”

“I can’t draw inside the lines.” Pouting, I said, “It’s really fustrating.”

“Not everyone gets it right on the first try, sweetie.” Picking up the crayon, Ms. Eliza said, “Here, I’ll show you a little trick from when I was your age.”

Grabbing another copy of the letter 'A', Ms. Eliza took the crayon and started drawing along the outside of the letter. Once she was finished, I looked at her and said, “What’s that for?”

“This is just to make the lines easier for you to see.” Handing me the crayon, Ms. Eliza said, “I’m sure you’ll have no trouble staying in the lines now.”

With Ms. Eliza watching me, I started coloring in the letter again. It only took me a few minutes to finish; this time I only strayed outside the line twice. Looking up at her, a smile on my face, I said, “Tanks Ms. Eliza.”

“No problem, sweetie.” Getting up, Ms. Eliza said, “Now finish the other two, because it’s almost time for lunch.”

After Ms. Eliza turned to walk off, Madison leaned over and said, “I knew you’d get it eventually, Lizzie.”
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Trouble Staying In The Lines

1112.content:
Before any of us could react, Mrs. Sullivan walked into the room and saw me standing in front of the mirror wearing the dress. Taking one look at me, she turned to Madison and said, “Madison, did you make a wish on that rock you showed me earlier?”

Aaron and I were both surprised when Madison slowly nodded and said, “After I made the wish, I threw it out the window.”

With a slight chuckle, Mrs. Sullivan turned to me and said, “Well...young lady, if you want to be a boy again, you’ll have to find that rock within the next 48 hours.”

I didn’t like why Mrs. Sullivan was implying. “What do you mean?”

“I didn’t find out until it was too late.” Sighing, Mrs. Sullivan said, “My time was up by the time I found the stone again; leaving me as the woman you see before you.”

Getting worried, I said, “How am I supposed to find a tiny rock in your yard?”

“It’ll be the same color as the clothes you were wearing before the wish was made.” Looking at me, Mrs. Sullivan said, “After I found it again, I decided to hold onto it; although I didn’t imagine my 5-year-old daughter searching my underwear drawer.”

“Sorry mommy.”

“It’s too late to look for it now.” Turning serious, Mrs. Sullivan said, “I’d start looking first thing in the morning, but you better move quickly.”

"Why?" Curious, Aaron asked.

“With each hour that goes by, the more people will start believing that Travis really is a 5 year old girl; even to the point where he’ll start believing it himself.” Pausing, looking at us, Mrs. Sullivan said. "The only reason I remember is because I held on to the wishing stone in hopes it won't trap anyone else."

I sighed, wanting to scream but as Mrs. Sullivan said, there was little I could do tonight.
1112.title: What happened before will happen again.

11121.content:
After listening to what Mrs. Sullivan had said about the wishing stone, it wasn’t a surprise to see that Mr. Sullivan only remembered me as a little girl. It did learn one crucial piece of information from talking with him – apparently, my name was now Elizabeth and my mom had dropped me off for the night while she went to work.

Once dinner was finished, and Mr. Sullivan went into the den to watch a pre-season baseball game, I decided that I wanted to get more answers. With Aaron and Madison following behind me, I made my way to Mr. and Mrs. Sullivan’s bedroom. Walking in, I found Mrs. Sullivan putting away some laundry.

Seeing us, she said, “What can I do for you three?”

“We want to know why you turned into a woman.”

“Well, I see you get right to the point.” Sighing, she said, “Have a seat on the bed and I’ll explain everything.”

With some help from Aaron, I soon found myself sitting next to Madison on the bed. Closing the door, Mrs. Sullivan said, “It all started about 16 years ago; about a year before Aaron was born. As far as Aaron and Madison are aware, their father and I met in college after being introduced through a mutual friend.”

“I guess you’re about to say that’s not really the truth?”

“It is, as far as your father and everyone else is concerned.” Pausing, Mrs. Sullivan said, “We did meet in college, but before the incident with the stone, your father and I were roommates. We’d been friends since Freshman year and did almost everything together.”

“Everything changed a few months before graduation; it was the weekend of Aunt Rachel’s wedding. Your father, over the previous few months, had been telling everyone about this amazing girlfriend he had; everyone expected that he’d bring her to the wedding. The only problem was that she didn’t exist – your father had made the whole thing up.” Pausing, Mrs. Sullivan said, “He was so desperate in the days leading up the wedding that I was worried he’d do something insane. It was the night before he was supposed to leave, and we’d just gotten back from a Frat party. I’d found this weird looking rock I was going to give to Uncle Ryan since he loved rocks.”

“You made a wish with the stone, didn’t you?”

“Do you want to finish the story, Aaron?” sighing, Mrs. Sullivan said, “Yes – I drunkenly wished that there was something I could do to help your father. Suddenly there was a shock from the stone and I dropped it – but that was only the beginning. By the time we’d gotten back to our dorm, it was evident something was happening to me. It wasn’t long before I’d gone from being a 6’3” muscular guy to a petite 5’5” woman.”

Curious, I said, “So what happened next?”

“We were both too drunk to do anything about the wish.” Sighing, Mrs. Sullivan said, “The next morning, after we’d sobered up, your father had the amazing idea to bring me to the wedding as his girlfriend. I refused to do it, but he convinced me otherwise. Anyway, we get the wedding and everyone is fawning over me as the girlfriend they’d heard so much about.”

“So what happened to keep you from turning back?”

“Please stop interrupting me, Aaron.” Pausing, Mrs. Sullivan said, “We get back to school after the wedding and manage to find the stone. We both tried dozens of times to undo the wish but nothing happened. I later found out about the 48-hour deadline – meaning I was stuck as a woman. By that point reality had started to change – I was no longer your father’s roommate, instead, I was a member of Alpha Epsilon Phi. We went our separate ways after that, I immersed myself in my new life while your father hung out with our former friends – who didn’t remember me being a guy.”

“Wait, you said this was about a year before I was born.”

“I was just getting to that part.” Turning to us, Mrs. Sullivan said, “About a month had passed since the wedding and I realized I hadn’t had a period since I became a girl. I took a pregnancy test and found out I was pregnant – the result of your father and I drunkenly having sex after the wedding. The rest is, as they say, history – I gave birth to Aaron 8 months later and we got married a few months after that.”

The three of us sat on the bed, taking in everything we’d just heard. Looking at his Mom, in disbelief, Aaron said, “I-I can’t believe you used to be a guy. You’re so...feminine.”

“Well, I’ve had 15 years to learn how to be a woman.” Looking at Aaron, she said, “For what it’s worth, you look a lot like me when I was your age.”

“Daddy doesn’t remember you used to be a guy?”

“No, sweetie, he doesn’t.” looking at Madison, Mrs. Sullivan said, “He started to forget soon after we got back. By the time I told him I was pregnant, he just remembered me being his girlfriend.”

“What does this mean for me?” concerned, I said, “It’s bad enough I’m a 5-year-old girl; I don’t want to be stuck like this.”

“Then we have to find that stone as soon as possible.”
11121.title: Getting Answers

111212.content:
I couldn’t sleep that night, as I kept replaying the conversation with Mrs. Sullivan in my head. After a while of tossing and turning, careful not to wake Madison, I got out of bed and walked out of the room. Making my way downstairs to the kitchen, I retrieved a flashlight and quietly walked outside. It was unseasonably chilly outside – not the kind of weather my Frozen nightie was made for.

Searching through the backyard wasn’t easy; I had to be careful not to wake anyone in the house. On top of all that, the stone could’ve ended up anywhere. As I searched through the garden alongside the house, careful not to trample Mrs. Sullivan’s plants, I finally spotted the stone nestled behind the machinery for the HVAC system. This was where I realized the benefits of being a young child – I was small enough to reach in and grab the stone.

Looking at it, I saw that it was a perfectly round stone with blue on the bottom and grey on top; matching the clothes I’d been wearing prior to the wish. “Thank goodness I found it!” sighing, I said, “Now Madison can reverse the wish!”

I carefully made my way back out of the garden, only for someone to smack my hand. I yelped in surprise and watched, horrified, as the stone fell from my hand and into the hands of an elderly woman. Looking at her, I saw she was wearing strange clothing; was around 5’6” and had long silver hair. From her appearance, she reminded me of a gypsy.

I couldn’t dwell on her appearance for too long, because she had something I needed. Screaming, I said, “That’s mine!”
An attempt to grab the stone back ended with my falling on my butt in the moist grass. “This is a cursed item, little girl.” Staring at me, with a cold look in her eyes, she said, “You should consider yourself lucky that I found you in time.”

At this point, I was getting desperate. Looking at her, I said, “Please, I need it to reverse a wish my friend’s sister made.”

The woman looked at me with a surprise. “So you’re the stone’s latest victim.” Laughing, she said, “If it’s any comfort, your friend will not be having a fun time either."

Looking at her, I gulped and said, “What do you mean...?”

"As I said, this is a cursed item.” Looking at me, she said, “Every wish comes with a price.”

“My friend’s mommy was changed by a wish.”

As I silently wondered why I said mommy, the woman looked at me and said, “I recently learned about her, which is why I’m here.” pausing, she said, “She wished to help a friend in need, but the price was having to start a new life in the process.”

Getting to my feet, I jumped for the stone again. “What about me?”

"Reversing a wish brings another price." Serious, the old woman said. "The question now is if it’s one you’re willing to pay.”

I wasn’t sure how to react to that. Taking advantage of my inaction, the woman ran out of the backyard.
111212.title: Enter a an old Gypsy.

1112122.content:
I started to run after her, desperate to get the stone back, but I was stopped by Mrs. Sullivan. Grabbing my arm as I ran by, she looked at me and said, “Travis, what do you think you’re doing?”

“I wanted to find the stone.” Pointing to the gate, I said, “I had it, but some old gypsy lady took it from me and ran off.”

“Gypsy lady?” pausing, Mrs. Sullivan said, “Was she wearing a necklace with a strange pendant on it?”

“Yeah, it had some weird symbol on it.” Looking at Mrs. Sullivan, I said, “How did you know about that?”

“A few weeks after I found out I was pregnant, a woman came snooping around the sorority house.” Looking at me, Mrs. Sullivan said, “My roommate found her in our room; said she was looking through my things. Before she ran to call the cops, she said the woman had a necklace with a pendant on it.”

“Was she looking for the stone?”

“I didn’t find that out until later; after I did a little research about the pendant.” Taking my hand, she said, “It seems there’s this strange cult surrounding the stones; they don’t like outsiders using them.”

As the two of us walked inside the house, I said, “The lady said it was cursed; that there was a price to pay with each wish made.” Looking at her, I said, “She said you paid the price by getting pregnant with Aaron, while Madison will have to pay a price as well.”

Mrs. Sullivan clearly didn’t like the idea that her daughter was going to be harmed by the stone. “It’s late, we’ll talk about this in the morning.” Walking me upstairs, she said, “I won’t tell your parents I found you walking around outside in the middle of the night.”

Stopping in my tracks, I said, “What did you say?”

Looking at me, Mrs. Sullivan said, “I said I won’t tell your mom about finding you outside.”

“No, that’s not what you said.” Looking at her, I said, “You said you wouldn’t tell my parents.”

Realizing what was going on, Mrs. Sullivan said, “It seems that we’re starting to feel the effects of reality changing.”

“I think you’re right.” Getting worried, I said, “Earlier, I said mommy instead of mom.”

“Mr. Sullivan has a doctor’s appointment tomorrow morning.” Looking at me, she said, “While he’s gone, the four of us will do some research and find a way to return you to normal.”
1112122.title: She Gets Away

choices: I try to search the attic.
Madison screams, she has paid for her wish.
11121222.content:
The following morning, Mrs Sullivan shook me awake before hushing me quiet. She had dark rings under her eyes and her breath had a strong smell of coffee to it. "I have been up all night researching that wishing stone." Tiredly, she whispered. "We need to have a talk."

I silently nodded and followed Mrs Sullivan our of Madison's bedroom to her private study where I found a coffee pot that was nearly empty next to a large stack of papers and books that dominated her desk around her computer. "You did this all for me?" Blushing, I asked.

"Well, for me as well in a way." Yawning, Mrs. Sullivan said. "The stone I had found years ago was one of seven. When brought together, they will grant the owner any one wish he, she, or they desire including vast wealth or immortality."

"But a single stone grants a wish too." Curious, I said.

Mrs Sullivan nodded. "Yes but for a price." Serious, she said. "Each stone represents one of the seven human desires. Irony, justice, love, revenge, knowledge, want, and regret."

I gulped at that. "What was the stone you and then Madison used?" Worried, I asked.

Mrs Sullivan sighed. "When you consider the price I paid, I would have to say that stone I had was irony." Softly, she said. "I had to live the life of a woman the man I married had made up just to have someone to brag about." She wiped a tear from her eye. "All because I wished there was some way I could help him."

I was touched by Mrs Sullivan's story so it hurt to have to ask, "Did you find a way to change me back in your research?"

Mrs Sullivan gave me a sad smile. "I found a way but you are not going to like it." Softly, she said. "There is an old book, which I have somewhere in the attic with an incantation that will reverse any wish within 48 hours of the wish being made."

"Just like the stone." Whispering, I said.

"The catch is I do not remember where in the attic I had put the book." Sadly, Mrs Sullivan said. "Also, your parents will be over within the hour to pick you up..."
11121222.title: The Next Morning

choices: Mommy Comes to Check On Us
111212223.content:
Before I could respond to that, we were interrupted by a loud scream coming from upstairs. Mrs. Sullivan ran upstairs and I followed behind her. Thanks to my shortened legs by the time I’d gotten upstairs, she’d already arrived outside the bathroom.

Coming up behind her, I saw Madison sitting on the toilet; her pajama pants resting at her feet. Wait a minute – we both wore nighties to bed. Before I could think about that further, I saw Aaron standing by the shower with a confused look on his face.

I suddenly felt very concerned about Madison. Squeezing past Mommy, I walked over to her. Looking at her, I said, “Are you okay?”

“Uh-huh.” Pointing at Aaron, she said, “He walked in on me when I was going potty.”

I watched as Mommy turned to Aaron. Before she could say anything, he said, “Madison forgot to lock the door again!”

“Aaron...err Travis, you should know you’re supposed to knock.” Sighing, Mommy said, “What if my girls had been taking a bath?”
“I’m sorry, I’ll be...wait. What did you call me?”

“Travis, of course.” Sighing, Mommy said, “Please knock next time; what if my girls had been taking a bath.”

“What’s going on here?” confused, Travis said, “Mom, my name’s not Travis.”

“Of course it is.” Looking at Travis, she said, “I’d appreciate it if you called me Mrs. Sullivan; I’m not your mother.”

Turning to look in the mirror, Travis was clearly surprised by the reflection he saw looking back at him. “What’s going on here?” looking at Madison and me, he said, “Why does Lizzie look like Madison?”

A part of me was aware that something was wrong, but I couldn’t quite put my finger on it. I knew that Travis was the 15-year-old son of one of mommy and daddy’s friends, but I also had a strange feeling that I was supposed to be Travis. But that was silly; I’ve always been Madison’s younger twin sister. Looking at Travis, I said, “Because we’re twins, silly!”

“Okay something really weird is going on here; I think it’s got something to do with that stone Madison had last night.” A confused look on his face, as if he was trying to figure out what was happening, Travis said, “I’m supposed to be your son Aaron, and Lizzie’s supposed to be my best friend Travis.”

Ignoring Travis for a moment, Mommy turned to Madison and me. “Girls, why don’t you go play in your room for a little while?”

“Okay, mommy.” Turning to Madison, I saw that she had the same confused look on her face as Travis. “Are you okay, Madison?”

“Yeah, I-I’m fine.” Looking at me, she said, “Let’s go have a tea party.”

While Travis looked on, Madison and I walked down the hall to our bedroom. Once we were far enough down the hall, I heard Mommy said, "Travis, honey, I think it's best if you don't come around here for a while." pausing, she said, "You're a good kid, but you're clearly dealing with something and I don't want my little girls exposed to it."

We walked out of earshot before Travis could respond. As we walked past the playroom; we walked past a framed photo – one of Daddy, Mommy, Madison and me at Disney World with Cinderella.

***********************


Madison and I were having a tea party with our stuffed animals when, a short time later, we heard a car honking its horn. We both went to the window as Travis walked out down the sidewalk. We watched as he stopped halfway down and looked back at the house; spotting us watching him from our bedroom window.

He stood there for a moment before walking over to his mommy and daddy as they stood in front of their car. Turning to Madison, I saw a sad look appear on her face – although I couldn’t figure out why.
111212223.title: Screaming From Upstairs

1112122231.content:
"Are you feeling better, Madison?" Softly, mom asked from the doorway. "You got what you think you wanted, did you not?"

I turned to mom... at least I thought it was mom... I shook my head as if to dismiss any doubt. "What are you talking about, mommy?" Confused, I asked.

It seemed very strange to call her 'mommy' as if it were wrong somehow. But how could it have been wrong? I was Madison's twin sister... wasn't I?

Mom sighed, a pained look on her face as she turned to me but she quickly hid it with a kind, patient smile. "Lizzie, why don't you go fetch a pair of pull ups for your sister." Pausing, Mom said, "I think you two need a nap after all this excitement."

I winced at that, somehow remembering that Madison wet the bed in her sleep. I noticed my sister wince even more, making me feel sorry for her.

Upon returning about a minute later, I saw Madison in tears and mom holding a cross look on her face. Again, she quickly hid it with a patient smile as she took the diaper from me. "I had to remind Madison that all mistakes, big and small, have a price." Stress in her voice, she said. "She made a mistake and now she has to live with the price it carried."

"What did she do?" Worried, I asked. "Forget to lock the bathroom door again?"

Mom shed a single tear. "Yes, honey." Softly, she said. "She forgot to lock the door again."

I gave mom some privacy as she helped Madison, crying harder, into her pull ups. Once we were in our beds and the light was turned off with the bedroom door closed, I turned to Madison who was still shedding tears. "Want to talk about it?" Softly, I asked.

Madison turned to me, tears falling before she...
1112122231.title: Mommy Comes to Check On Us

11121222312.content:
Tears falling down her face, Madison looked at me and said, “Do you remember that stone mommy told us about last night?”

I vaguely remembered something about a stone, but I couldn’t figure out what it was. Looking at Madison, I said, “I think so, why?”

“I made a wish last night that I’d have a best friend.” Pausing, Madison said, “The wish came true; but not exactly in the way I hoped.”

“What do you mean?”

“Travis used to be my...our brother Aaron.”

“What are you talking about, Maddy?” confused, I said, “We don’t have a brother.”

“That’s the thing, Lizzie” looking at me, Madison said, “You’re not supposed to be my twin sister.”

“Huh?”

“You’re supposed to be Travis; Aaron’s best friend.”
11121222312.title: Gave a vague answer

111212223121.content:
I looked at Madison for a moment, not certain how to react. Part of me knew what she was saying was true but it was a very small part... pounding on the back of my mind. This caused me to wince before doing the only thing I could do... I giggled. "You are silly sis." smiling, I said. "If you did make a wish, why don't you just find the book?"

Madison looked at me, surprised and somewhat hopeful. "What book?"

"The book mommy told me she had hidden somewhere in the attic." Honestly, I said. "She told me that it would reverse any wish once without a price... or something like that."

Madison's mood seemed to improve, hearing that. "Do you know where it the attic it might be?'

I shrugged. "I dunno." then I smiled, seeing Madison happy again. "We could look for it after our nap; it'll be an adventure."

Madison smiled more. "Okay!"

We both went back to sleep after that with anticipations of an adventure together; although, unknown to me, Madison had another reason to find the book.
111212223121.title: My Reaction

1112122231211.content:
After Madison and I woke up for our naps, we ran downstairs to find Mommy working on something at the kitchen table. Seeing us standing there, she smiled and said, “Hello girls; did you have a good nap?”

“Yes mommy!”

“I’ve got some good news.” Pausing, Mommy said, “Your father just called; his plane just landed, he’ll be home in an hour.”

A small part of me, the same part that had been pounding at the back of my head earlier, told me that Daddy had been here last night. But I knew that was silly; since Daddy had been on a business trip. Needless to say, Madison and I could barely contain our excitement; after all, what little girls wouldn’t want to see their daddy. After we’d stopped jumping around in excitement, I said,
“Mommy, can you get our costume trunk out of the attic?”

“I suppose so.” Smiling, Mommy said, “Do you girls want to play dress up?”

“Uh-huh!”

We then followed Mommy back upstairs; stopping outside the door that led upstairs to the attic. Turning to us, she said, “You girls can come upstairs with me; just be careful.”

“Okay Mommy!”
1112122231211.title: That Afternoon

choices: It was in a strange language.
11121222312111.content:
Upon entering the attic, Madison immediately began rummaging through every box she could reach, looking for something. She was mumbling something as she did so. "Please be here..." Tearing up, she muttered. "Please be in here somewhere..."

"What are you looking for, sis?" Curious, I asked.

"A book." Searching another box, Madison replied. "It's an old book mommy said I could read."

Madison's excitement quickly turned into confusion and frustration as she gazed into the book she had found. "What language is this?"

"It's witch writing." Softly, mom said. she then whispered, "Why do you think I hid it?"

"You don't know witch writing...?" Tearfully, Madison asked.

Mom shook her head. "You would need a witch to translate and they do not do anything for anyone for free." Sadly, she replied. "Also, you need to know where to look to find one."

"What are you two talking about?" Curious, I asked.

"Madison was looking for a book i had told her about but she can't read it." Patiently, mom replied. "Only it is in a language neither she or I understand."

"May I see?" Still curious, I asked.

Mom sighed and handed me the book. I looked at it and shrugged. "They look like stick figures doing a dance."

Mom giggled. "They do, don't they?"

"Do we know anyone who can read it or some book that can tell us what it says?" Worried, Madison asked. "Please, mommy..."

Mom again sighed. "The only one I know who can translate it is..."
